author: Jacob Gallagher
title: Off-the-Field Style Tips From Victor Cruz
text:
1 COMMENTS ENLARGE Style role model Victor Cruz Illustration: Isaac Bonan OPEN UP wide receiver Victor Cruz’s locker at MetLife Stadium, and you’d no doubt find the New York Giant’s number 80 royal-blue jersey. You may also discover a color-blocked Ovadia & Sons sweater or a checked Hugo Boss BOSS 2.01 % suit. In the past couple years, Mr. Cruz, 28, has immersed himself in the world of high fashion, attending runway shows, modeling in an ad campaign for French label Givenchy and designing a small collection with cult denim brand 3x1. He recently became spokesperson for Boss Bottled, the Hugo Boss fragrance line.
He insists his interest in fashion goes deeper than the attendant perks. “I’m not just in it for the free clothing,” he said. To seek inspiration for his 3x1 collection, for instance, the athlete traveled to Japan for a crash course on the craft of denim production.
Though sidelined by an injury a year ago, Mr. Cruz has been working his way back onto the field. As befits an athlete of his stature, he believes that fitness and fashion go hand-in-hand. “Staying in shape is definitely what’s going to give you the confidence to wear the clothes that you want,” he said. Here, Mr. Cruz gives us the play-by-play on the rest of his wardrobe strategy.
ENLARGE Clockwise from bottom left: an Ovadia & Sons s/s 2016 runway look; Kith varsity jacket; Hugo Boss suit; Rolex watch; Thom Browne sweatpants; Public School shirt; brooch; stickpin; a Fall 2015 Ovadia & Sons runway look; Berluti shoes Photo: Marko Metzinger for The Wall Street Journal (shirt, sweatpants, shoes, brooch & stickpin); F. Martin Ramin/The Wall Street Journal (shirt), styling by Anne Cardenas; Getty Images (model) Beautifully Basic
“Public School’s buttondowns fit me perfectly. They’re exactly my aesthetic. I like their generous cut and fit. They give me that feeling of security, of strength.” Public School Shirt, $495, saksfifthavenue.com
Gilt Milestone
“A gold Rolex was my first big purchase when I made it to the NFL. It’s near to my heart. Growing up, I saw guys in suits with a nice watch. I always wanted to be that guy.” Oyster Perpetual Day-Date 40 Watch, $34,850, rolex.com
Browsing IRL
“I’m an online shopper but I still like to go inside stores and see what they have—Barneys New York, Kith’s new store in Brooklyn, and I love the Rag & Bone store. It’s great.”
Tailored Bling
“With suiting I like to take risks so I try things such as lapel pins. I like vintage ones from hole-in-the-wall places I find when I’m traveling in London, Paris or Los Angeles.” Brooch, $450, Camilla Dietz Bergeron, 212-794-9100 ; Stickpin, $2,250, Fred Leighton, 212-288-1872
On Track
“People used to think if you wore sweats you hadn’t woken up yet. Now the tapered-sweatpants look is the thing. Thom Browne has a really good pair that I wear all the time.” Thom Browne Sweatpants, $490, mrporter.com
Vest Dressed
“A few years ago, I would never have worn a three-piece suit. It’s not your everyday look. But I just got my first one from Hugo Boss and now I want to wear more of them.” Boss Suit, $1,095, hugoboss.com
Craft Considerations
“Berluti opened my eyes to craftsmanship; every shoe is made by hand. It’s not just buying a shoe because you like it but because of how it’s made. They’re not cheap and when you invest in something, you want to make sure you have it for life.” Leather Shoe, $2,130, Berluti, 212-439-6400
Laser-Focused On Labels
“Some of my favorite brands are Hugo Boss, Public School, Rag & Bone, Todd Snyder, Neil Barrett, Ovadia & Sons. Who else? Givenchy, of course. Lanvin. That’s pretty much it.”
Corrections & Amplifications
Victor Cruz is a spokesperson for the fragrance Boss Bottled. An earlier version of this article incorrectly referred to it as Bottled.
